newsitem.title: UK: Med oil products-gas oil, some fuel up, others not.
newsitem.headline: Med oil products-gas oil, some fuel up, others not.

text.p: Mediterranean oil products were mixed on Friday, with some gainers and others losers.
Gasoline was steady, failing to follow the fall in NYMEX futures or the rebound in NWE physical prices.
"The Med is fundamentally a weaker market...Demand is very thin, except perhaps for higher octane grades," said a trader.
Naphtha also held steady despite the bearish tone created by the reopening of the Skikda terminal.
Traders said one delayed cargo was headed for Brazil, while two others in the hands of a trading house were earmarked for the U.S.
Traders pegged the market at around cif quotes high +$3/$4 a tonne cif Med.
Gas oil rose about $2.00 in line with Nov IPE futures, but most trade in the Mediterranean was on floating prices.
Heating oil was still under some pressure, partly due to thin activity on both sides, but diesel premiums rose sharply after a cargo was talked above Nov IPE +$30 cif France.
A Russian cargo was sold at quotes high +75 cents cif Genoa.
High sulphur cracked fuel took sustenance from Romanian demand which lurks in the background as a pillar of support. A second trade was talked, but not confirmed.
"It's very hard to pin down exactly what is happening," said one trader at a major. Prices in the Med were assessed marginally under $120 fob Med, but this could well be broken next week.

Low sulphur cracked cargoes were slightly weaker with a late deal done out of Scandinavia on a 50:50 fixed/floating basis, fixed at $132 cif NWE cif Milazzo. The trade was the fourth purchase by the main Med buyer at increasingly lower numbers.
But, despite the softer prices, most traders said the market was fundamentally still firm.
